newsitem.title: RUSSIA: Russian shares fall, seen to slip further.
newsitem.headline: Russian shares fall, seen to slip further.

text.p: Leading Russian shares fell on Wednesday in small volumes on worries over President Boris Yeltsin's health, traders said.
They forecast the fall will continue in the next few days.
The Russian Trading System index of 21 leading issues fell by 3.37 percent to 175.88.
"The market got sick, most probably on the reports about Yeltsin's sickness," said Alexei Dolgikh, chief trader from Troika-Dialog brokerage.

Prices started falling on Tuesday on a report in the U.S. magazine Time that Yeltsin needs round-the-clock monitoring and the Kremlin was considering sending him to a Swiss hospital for a bypass operation.

Yeltsin aides deny he is ill, and said he was resting in Russia's north-western lakeland. Interfax news agency said Yeltsin was returning to the Moscow area on Wednesday and would be back to the Kremlin on Thursday. But a Kremlin spokesman said he could not confirm the report.
Peter Kizenko, head of sales and trading at ING-bank, said that despite the fall in prices there were still buyers on the market.
"Buyers are staying on the market -- they are interested in even lower prices," he said.
Dolgikh said prices would most likely fall further on Thursday. "It is a very quiet day," he said. "Prices are falling on small volumes."
Mosenergo closed at $0.95 after $0.96 on Tuesday, UES fell to $0.0765 from $0.0795, LUKoil fell to $9.40 from $9.75 and Norilsk Nickel was $7.50 after $7.70.
